001package io.jstach.jstachio.escapers;
002
003import java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets;
004
005import io.jstach.jstache.JStacheConfig;
006import io.jstach.jstache.JStacheContentType;
007import io.jstach.jstachio.Escaper;
008
009/**
010 * Provides a mustache spec based HTML escaper which is the default in normal mustache.
011 * <p>
012 * The escaper simply escapes:
013 * <ul>
014 * <li>'&quot;'</li>
015 * <li>'&gt;'</li>
016 * <li>'&lt;'</li>
017 * <li>'&amp;'</li>
018 * </ul>
019 *
020 * <em>N.B. Unlike many XML escapers this escaper does not differentiate attribute and
021 * element content. Furthermore Mustache unlike many other templating languages is content
022 * agnostic. If more flexibile attribute escaping is needed a custom lambda could be used
023 * to preserve the whitespace in attributes. </em>
024 * <p>
025 * <strong>This escaper assumes UTF-8 which is the predominate encoding of HTML these days
026 * and thus will not encode characters other then the ones mentioned above. </strong> Thus
027 * if you intend escape for example {@link StandardCharsets#US_ASCII} a different HTML
028 * escaper should be used to properly escape non ascii characters as HTML entities.
029 *
030 * @author agentgt
031 * @author Victor Nazarov
032 * @see JStacheConfig#contentType()
033 */
034@JStacheContentType(mediaType = "text/html", charsets = { "UTF-8" })
035public final class Html {
036
037        private Html() {
038        }
039
040        /**
041         * Provides the escaper.
042         * @return HTML escaper.
043         */
044        public static Escaper provider() {
045                return HtmlEscaper.Html;
046        }
047
048        /**
049         * Provides the escaper.
050         * @return HTML escaper.
051         */
052        public static Escaper of() {
053                return HtmlEscaper.Html;
054        }
055
056}
